Tax brackets are organized by income level. In the US, there are eight tax brackets with different marginal tax rates, ranging from 10% for the lowest bracket to 37% for the highest bracket. An individual's tax liability is determined by calculating their marginal tax rate for each bracket and adding them up, with the final total being their effective tax rate.

In your case, as a single filer under 65 years old in 2021, the federal tax brackets and marginal tax rates are as follows:
Taxable Income                    Marginal Tax Rate

0 to $9,875                        10%

$9,875 to $40,125                  12%

$40,125 to $85,525                 22%

$85,525 to $163,375                24%

$163,375 to $207,350               32%

$207,350 to $616,375               35%

$616,375 and above                 37%

Your income of $50,000 puts you in the 22% tax bracket. Thus, your marginal tax rate is 22%, and you will pay that rate on every dollar of taxable income above $40,125 (the bottom of the 22% bracket). Your total tax liability is then calculated by multiplying your marginal tax rate by your taxable income:

$50,000 - $40,125 = $9,875 x 0.22 = $2,150

So, your income tax for summer is $2,150, which puts the answer closest to it as B.

State income tax: $6,534.95
Total income tax: $28,897.45

$$

Tax liability = Income tax - Tax credits
$$

The federal income tax is a progressive tax, meaning that your tax rate increases as your income increases. To calculate your tax liability, you first need to determine your taxable income, which is your total income minus any deductions and exemptions. In this case, your only deduction will be the standard deduction of $13,050, since you are not itemizing deductions. This means that your taxable income will be $86,950 (100,000 - 13,050).

Once you have your taxable income, you can use the tax rates to calculate your tax liability. In 2021, the tax rates for a single filer range from 10% to 37%.
